topic.title: HPE Helion OpenStack 2.0: Removing a Swift Node

body.p: This process is used when you want to remove one or more node(s) permanently from the Swift system. This process has three phases and are as follows:

ul.li: Removing the node's drives from the rings - move data off the node and store it on the remaining nodes.
Disabling Swift on the node - prevent the node from participating in the Swift system.
Removing the node from the input model - the node is removed completely from the system.

section.title: Removing a Node's Drive from the Rings
section.p: To remove a node's drives from the rings, use the following steps. Change the role of the server that is being removed so that it uses that disk model that does not include Swift drives. Then a new ring is built and deployed. The new rings will not contain the node's drives.

ol.li:
Edit the definition of the server (usually in data/servers.yml file). For example, if the entry for the server looks like:- name: SWOBJ-DISKS - id: swobj4 ip-addr: 192.168.10.5 role: SWOBJ-ROLE server-group: RACK3 ...
Change the role to a new value â€“ for example: SWOBJ-DRAINING-ROLE- name: SWOBJ-DISKS - id: swobj4 ip-addr: 192.168.10.5 role: SWOBJ-DRAINING-ROLE server-group: RACK3 ...

Edit the server-roles definition (usually in data/server_roles.yml file) and add the SWOBJ-DRAINING-ROLE role. Keep the interface model of the original SWOBJ-ROLE, but change the disk model to SWOBJ-DRAINING-DISKS as shown in the following example:- name: SWOBJ-ROLE interface-model: INTERFACE_SET_SWOBJ disk-model: SWOBJ-DISKS
- name: SWOBJ-DRAINING-ROLE interface-model: INTERFACE_SET_SWOBJ disk-model: SWOBJ-DRAINING-DISKS

Create a SWOBJ-DRAINING-DISKS disk model by editing the file containing the SWOBJ-DISKS disk model (usually data/swobj_disks.yml file) and adding an entry for SWOBJ-DRAINING-DISKS. Make a copy of the SWOBJ-DISKS disk model, but change the consumer field from "swift" to "swift-draining". For example:disk-models: - name: SWOBJ-DISKS volume-groups: - name: hlm-vg ... consumer: name: os device-groups: - name: swiftobj devices: - name: /dev/sdb - name: /dev/sdc - name: /dev/sdd consumer: name: swift attrs: rings: - object-0
- name: SWOBJ-DRAINING-DISKS volume-groups: - name: hlm-vg ... consumer: name: os device-groups: - name: swiftobj devices: - name: /dev/sdb - name: /dev/sdc - name: /dev/sdd consumer: name: swift-draining attrs: rings: - object-0Before you run any playbooks, remember that you need to export the encryption key in the following environment variable: export HOS_USER_PASSWORD_ENCRYPT_KEY=<encryption key> See Installation for Helion Entry Scale Cloud with Swift Only for more details.
Commit the changes to git.cd ~/helion git commit -a -m "<commit message>"
Run the configuration processor:cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
Run the following command to create a deployment directory.cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml
Run the swift-deploy.yml playbook. Do not limit to just the node (helion-cp1-swobj4) that you are draining.cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts swift-deploy.yml

Wait until replication has finished. See for more details.
At this stage, all data has been moved from helion-cp1-swobj4 and replicated on the remaining nodes. Now, you can proceed to the next phase.

section.p: The node is still running Swift services. It is still part of the input model and is fully configured so you can log in and perform the other operations.

To disable the node, use the following steps. In this example, swobj4 is the node being removed from Swift.
Stop Swift services on the node using the swift-stop.yml playbook andcd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts swift-stop.yml --limit <hostname>
In the following example, you execute the command to stop Swift services on the node and limits the helion-cp1-swobj0004 as follows:cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts swift-stop.yml --limit helion-cp1-swobj0004When using the --limit you must specify the full hostname (for example: helion-cp1-swobj0004) or use the wildcard * (for example: *swobj4*).
Remove configuration files as follows. This assumes you are logged onto the deployer:ssh helion-cp1-swobj4-mgmt sudo rm -R /etc/swiftDo not run any other playbooks until you have finished the process described in the Removing a node from the input model. Otherwise, these playbooks may recreate /etc/swift and restart Swift on swobj4. If you accidentally run a playbook, simply repeat the process described Disabling Swift on a Node.

title.b: Removing a node from the input model

section.p:
Use the following steps to remove a node.
Edit the servers list (usually in data/servers.yml file). Remove the entry for the node (swobj4 in this example).
If this was a SWPAC node, reduce the member-count attribute by 1 in the control-planes definition (usually in data/control_plane.yml file). For SWOBJ nodes, no such action is needed.
Commit the changes to git:cd ~helion git commit -a -m "<commit message>"
Run the configuration processor:cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
Run the following command to create a deployment directory.cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml
Remove the node from cobbler as follows:sudo cobbler system remove --name=swobj4 ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost cobbler-deploy.yml
If the node was a SWPAC node, run the hlm-deploy.yml playbook as follows:cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts hlm-deploy.yml
Wait until replication has finished. See for more details.
Further rebalances of the rings may be necessary. Use the process described in Final rebalance phase at .
